_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Isabela Sewage Treatment Plant is located at the Carretera #4466 Km 1.9 Interior Camino Municipal #5 Sector Villa Pesquera Bo. Guayaba Isabela, Puerto Rico, 00662.  This wastewater treatment plant is owned by Puerto Rico Aqueducts and Sewers Authority (PRASA) which is a Government Agency.  PRASA has developed the RMP following the Program #3 for the Management and Prevention of Risks associated with the storage and handling of the toxic substance used as for water disinfection: Chlorine.  The RMP was prepared in compliance with EPA 40 CFR Part 68.  The Prevention Program was prepared in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, as established in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.

Accidental Release:
It is PRASA policy to comply with EPA and OSHA Federal and State applicable requirements.  Chlorine is a toxic substance regulated by EPA, for that reason Isabela Sewage Treatment Plant is observing the appropriated engineering controls.  Changes have been put in place to improve security and as a part of the Prevention Plan implanted to protect the wellness of workers, employees, contractors, visitors and immediately surrounding areas and inhabitants.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance handled.
Isabela Sewage Treatment Plant is located close to the coastal area where the plant discharges the treated water.  The chlorine is used as a disinfectant to destroy the microorganism that could cause illness in humans.  The chlorine is delivered from the PRASA Storage center in Puerto Nuevo to the plant in one (1) ton containers.  Isabela Sewage Treatment Plant could have a storage maximum volume of 12,000 lbs distributed in six (6) containers.  The containers are connected to regular valves and through them the chlorine flows to two (2) vacuum chlorinators.  From the chlorinators, the dosified chlorine flows to the injectors and then the chlorinated water is sent to one (1) injection point at the end of plant?s process. 

Worst Case Scenario:
The Worst Cas

e Scenario was determined as indicated in the EPA Wastewater Treatment Plant, as per Appendix F Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.  This guidance considers the release of the Chlorine Gas of the entire container (2,000 lbs) during 10 minutes and other specifications related to the weather conditions and a radio of 1.3 miles, for a chlorine concentration equal or higher than 3 ppm, which is the American Industrial Hygiene Association exposure limit above which it is determined human health will be affected.  Using the Landview 6 Simulator and the US Census 2000, it was identified that 12,780 residents are inside the 1.3 miles radio.  Besides the beach area, no other known environmental receptors (state parks, or official designated wildlife preserves) are located within this radio area.  The ALOHA Modeling Dispersion Program was used to simulate the gas dispersion.

Alternative Case Scenario:
The more realistic scenario was also simulated as per EPA Wastewater Treatment Plants parameters, as a release of the total content of a 2,000 lbs container, but throughout a pipe leak.  In the case the end point distance is calculated at 0.1 miles and no public receptors were identified over the most recent map.  No known environmental receptors are located within this radio area.

General Accident Release Prevention Program 
PRASA is actually in a very aggressive operation to implement a Prevention Plan to ensure the maintenance and mechanical integrity of the facility which will improve significantly the safety scope of the current prevention plans.  Standard Operational Procedures (SOP?s) are already in place to comply the OSHA and PROSHO requirements in order to keep all the involved parties aware of the hazardous and risk related to the chlorine.  List of all SOP?s are indicated in the PSM report and are located in the plant.

Emergency Response Program:
PRASA has various SOP?s to manage emergency programs associated to a release

of the chemical and also related to the emergency actions to be taken before and after hurricanes and other atmospherics events.

Five years Accident History:
No mayor release of chlorine in excess of ten (10) lbs has been reported during the last five years. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
It is recommended to eliminate the use of flexible tubing (serpentina) as containers flange. It is still needed to reinforced administrative activities related to Containers handling and transportation, employee?s training, preventive maintenance and audits. Recommendations were given on that regard on last PHA dated 12/12/2007.
